study_plan_entry.title: Methods of asymptotic analysis in mechanics

free_text.Learning outcomes: The objective is to introduce starting PhD students (and selected undergraduates) to the most important methods of asymptotic analysis used to construct simplified (analytical) models in mechanics.[br/]This is achieved through a combination of  lectures, common problem solving and class discussions.[br/]
free_text.Content: The following topics are covered:[br/]- Problem solutions in terms of series and asymptotic series[br/]- Ordering parameters and asymptotic analysis[br/]- Asymptotic approximation of integrals (methods of stationary phase and of steepest descent applied to Fourier inversions, etc.)[br/]- Singular perturbations - Matched asymptotic expansions (generalized boundary layer approximation) with examples (correction to Stokes drag of a sphere, etc.)[br/]- Multi-scale methods with examples (flows with "slow" streamwise evolution such as developed flow in a tube with variable properties, waves evolving in slowly varying media, etc.)[br/]
free_text.Keywords: asymptotic expansions, singular perturbations, multiple scales, WKB[br/]
free_text.Note: The course is principally based on the book "Perturbation Methods in the Computer Age" by David C. Wilcox (ISBN 0963605127 -- published 1995 by DCW Industries, La Canada, California)[br/][br/]
